import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

source.b10af12a:
Scores = Scores.replace('#NULL!',np.nan).dropna()
print(Scores.dtypes)
Scores[['pdi','idv','mas','uai','ltowvs','ivr']] = Scores[['pdi','idv','mas','uai','ltowvs','ivr']].apply(lambda x: x.astype(int),axis = 0)
print(Scores.dtypes)
print(Scores.head())
source.d97b32b8:
fig,ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (15,10),nrows = 3, ncols = 2)
ax[0,0].barh(Scores.sort_values('pdi')['ctr'][0:19],Scores.sort_values('pdi')['pdi'][0:19])
ax[0,0].set_yticklabels(Scores.sort_values('pdi')['ctr'][0:19],size = 7)
ax[0,0].set_title('Power Distance Index')
ax[0,1].barh(Scores.sort_values('idv')['ctr'][0:19],Scores.sort_values('idv')['idv'][0:19])
ax[0,1].set_yticklabels(Scores.sort_values('idv')['ctr'][0:19],size = 7)
ax[0,1].set_title('Individualism vs Collectivism')
ax[1,0].barh(Scores.sort_values('mas')['ctr'][0:19],Scores.sort_values('mas')['mas'][0:19])
ax[1,0].set_yticklabels(Scores.sort_values('mas')['ctr'][0:19],size = 7)
ax[1,0].set_title('Masculinity vs Femeninity')
ax[1,1].barh(Scores.sort_values('uai')['ctr'][0:19],Scores.sort_values('uai')['uai'][0:19])
ax[1,1].set_yticklabels(Scores.sort_values('uai')['ctr'][0:19],size = 7)
ax[1,1].set_title('Uncertainty Avoidance Index')
ax[2,0].barh(Scores.sort_values('ltowvs')['ctr'][0:19],Scores.sort_values('ltowvs')['ltowvs'][0:19])
ax[2,0].set_yticklabels(Scores.sort_values('ltowvs')['ctr'][0:19],size = 7)
ax[2,0].set_title('Long term vs Short term orrientation')
ax[2,1].barh(Scores.sort_values('ivr')['ctr'][0:19],Scores.sort_values('ivr')['ivr'][0:19])
ax[2,1].set_yticklabels(Scores.sort_values('ivr')['ctr'][0:19],size = 7)
ax[2,1].set_title('Indulgence vs Restraint')
plt.show()
source.50077702:
from scipy.cluster.hierarchy import linkage, dendrogram
mergings = linkage(Scores[['pdi','idv','mas','uai','ltowvs','ivr']],
                   method = 'complete') 

fig,ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (15,10))
fig1 = dendrogram(mergings,
          labels = list(Scores['country']),
          leaf_rotation = 90,
          leaf_font_size = 9,
          color_threshold = 100)
plt.title('Dendrogram of Cultural Attributes')
plt.show()

fig,ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (15,10))
fig1 = dendrogram(mergings,
          labels = list(Scores['country']),
          leaf_rotation = 90,
          leaf_font_size = 9,
          color_threshold = 60)
plt.title('Dendrogram of Cultural Attributes\nCluster coloring at 60')
plt.show()
source.6d3e7428: Cluster analysis to see which countries are most similar.  Data is not scaled or standardized as each dimension is on a set 0-100 scale by default.
source.4530aa8e: Replace "#NULL!" values with numpy nan and then drop any incomplete rows
source.0e20d453: The above chart shows how closely related two particular cultures are to one another based on the 6 dimension within the data set.  As an example, Australia and USA are very closely related as shown by the very low measurement of the split between them (as measured by the y axis).
source.941317e4: Correlation plot of all dimesions, looking for any colinearity
source.c19a7d80: Basic visualizations of scores by nation, top 20 for each dimension
source.6146c22b:
Hofstede's cultural dimension data is a collection of 6 different dimension scores for multiple countries. 

This notebook takes a look at how similar cultures are based on the distance in a hierarchical clustering as illustrated by a dendrogram.  The exact reasons for the proximity between two specific countries is far beyond this notebook and may have multiple possible conributing factors.
